Ecomate. UNDP requested our assistance in program for blowing agent phase out in Article 5 countries. Transitioned all customers out of HCFCs ahead of regulatory deadline.  
2009 - Received GRAS (Generally Recognized As Safe) approval
2016 - Spoke at UNFCCC Conference of Parties (COP22) to educate on Carbon Offset Methodology & “green” options for CFC, HCFC, & HFC elimination.
2017 - Recipient of American Carbon Registry Innovation Award for our work on Carbon Offset Methodology.

Foam Supplies Inc. is committed to continuing its commitment to safety and the environment. Below are recent / upcoming events meant to improve safety at our facility. 
2022 - Will be the first to eliminate HFCs from the product portfolio near year end. More than 3 years ahead of regulatory deadline.
2022 - 85+% of products are sold in “closed loop” systems to mitigate human and environmental exposure.

2022 - Employees involved in the handling of Methyl Formate or the processes that use it are scheduled to complete HAZWOPER training in 2022.
2022 Additional Training Completed
IATA training – 16 employees 
IMDG training – 21 employees 
DOT training – 27 employees 
HAZWOPER 24 – 2 employees

Formic Acid Spill Procedures
1.	Evacuate then Evaluate - DO NOT try to upright spilled container at this time.
2.	Set-up Personal Protection Equipment and Ventilation:
Rubber Boots
Chemical Resistant Apron
Chemical Resistant Gloves
Full-face Organic Vapor Cartridge Mask
3.	Contain Spill
Floor Dry, Pigs, etc.
4.	Neutralize with “Garden Lime” or Sodium Bicarbonate”
		Keep 40 lb. bag of Garden Lime in Spill Cart
5.	Clean Up
Put in Open Top Drums
Leave lid off. Store outside. Protect from rain and other elements.
6.	Dispose
Methyl Formate Spill Procedure
Spills of 1-Gallon or Less
Contain the flow of the material with absorbent PIGs if necessary. Wipe up material with rags or absorb with floor dry. Place PIGs, rags and/or floor dry into open top waste drum designated for this purpose.
Spill of 1-Gallon – 5-Gallons
Close access doors to other parts of the building. Open outside doors. Contain the flow of the material with absorbent PIGs. Soak up with floor dry. Place floor dry and PIGs into open top drum designated for this purpose.
Spills Greater Than 5-Gallons
Evacuate the area. Designated safety personal will make decision to call fire department or take other action. 
Planned changes to improve safety
Below is a summary of what Foam Supplies Inc. has done in the past to improve safety and reduce environmental impact. 
1986 - First company to patent and develop HCFCs technology. First to eliminate CFCs from product portfolio. Patented “solventless” dispensing technology to eliminate Methylene Chloride solvent flushing which was the standard in industry.
1990 - First to develop and market HFC technology to allow for elimination of HCFCs.
1998 - Began development of methyl formate (aka Ecomate) technology to eliminate HFCs.
2002 - Awarded patent on Ecomate technology.
2003 - Ecomate approved by the U.S. EPA to replace harmful HFCs and HCFCs in the foam blowing industry under the Significant New Alternatives Policy (SNAP) program.
2004 - Awarded VOC-Exempt status for

Adding Formic Acid
Step 1
Formic Acid can be added in two ways. One way is it can be pumped in through a drum pump which is attached to the mixing vessel pump intake. This is a closed system except where the drum pump goes into the drum. Another way is for adding smaller quantities, a five gallon plastic pail may be filled from the drum spout then poured into the add pot and chased with chemical from the mixing vessel. The pail must be drained completely then can be rinsed with water. Turn on any available ventilation and warn people in the work area who could be affected by fumes. 
When handling Formic Acid always wear: 
Chemical Apron
Chemical Resistant Gloves
Full Face Organic Cartridge Respirator
Adding Methyl Formate
Step 1
Before adding MF (Ecomate) the mixing vessel head space must be purged with nitrogen. This must be repeated anytime the vessel fills with air. Normal procedure will be to have the vessel replenish with nitrogen as it is unloaded so the vessel is always depleted of air. To purge the head space, pressurize the head space with nitrogen to 15 psi (be sure the vessel is rated to handle 15 psi) then blow down. Repeat 3 times.
Step 2
MF will be stored in a pressurize tank such as our F6000 or F1000. It should be maintained at 25 psi nitrogen pressure.
Step 3
To add MF to the batch in the mix vessel use the supplied transfer hose. Do not use any other hose unless directed by the engineering department. This hose should have a check valve to keep system from the mixing vessel out of the MF tank. This hose should have a ball valve at both ends so no MF is lost during connecting or disconnecting the hose. The hose should be added under the liquid level of the system in the mixing vessel through the connection on the side of the tank. There should be a grounding cable connecting the MF tank to the mixing vessel while transferring chemica

F2 – Incident Assessment Form

Use this form to determine the extent of the emergency situation.
The actual assessment assigns an incident severity level to the current situation such as low, medium, and high.  Based on this assessment, other actions such as escalation may take place.  
The severity levels may be based on extend of injury, possibility of containment, or other scenarios specific to your organization.  Example severity levels are described below:
•	Low – incidents considered as low priority do not involve injury; can be contained easily, and not likely to progress.

•	Medium – incidents considered medium priority involve minor injuries; may not be easily contained and have a chance of progressing.

•	High – incidents considered as high priority involve injuries minor or major; are not easily contained and have a high probability progressing.

Incident Assessment Form

l Emergency & Fire Evacuation Procedure
Description
This procedure provides guidelines for evacuation. Consider the following during an evacuation:
•	Assist others.  For example, consider the needs of people with disabilities
•	Outside Temperatures
•	Where to evacuate to.  For example, evacuate to a safer place, not into danger
Priority should be given to safety of staff and public.  In general, you should ensure:

1.	Everyone is accounted for;

2.	Evacuation has been carried out;

3.	Medical and First Aid staff attend to casualties, if required; and

4.	Ambulance service has been called, if required.

General Emergency & Fire Evacuation Procedure Steps
If evacuation is required, take the following steps as necessary:
If you are NOT a floor warden:
Remain calm

Do not return to your office/work area

Activate Alarm

Alert Fire Warden

Alert the Emergency Response Team Leader and Facility Security Manager

Do not take valuable objects that hinder or block the evacuation routes

Leave the premises immediately by:
Using the nearest escape route; and/or by 
Following the Floor Wardens instructions
Do not use elevators
If you ARE a floor warden, follow Floor Warden Evacuation Procedure:
(You are responsible for your assigned area)

If possible, perform these tasks:

•	Activate the alarm
•	Alert the Emergency Response Team Leader and Facility Security Manager
•	Commence evacuation of your area by providing clear instructions
•	Guide staff to evacuation area
•	Do not use elevators
•	Ensure staff do not take large size objects
•	Ensure escape route is not congested; use alternate exit if possible
•	Search the floor or area to ensure that no one is left behind
•	Check for abnormal conditions or objects (bomb threat etc.)
•	Perform equipment is shutdown tasks (e.g., plant machinery should be shutdown, if practical)
•	Perform building shutdown tasks (e.g., ensure doors are closed, but not locked)

If this is a fire: 

1.	If safe to do so and condition permit, contain fire by e

personnel, and visitors to report the incident.  
If possible, the incident shall be reported to the following:
Public Authorities (Police, Fire, Ambulance), if appropriate
•	Emergency Response Team Leader or alternate
•	Facility Security Manager
•	Senior Management Staff

Example emergency events are:
•	explosion
•	overheated equipment
•	airplane crash
•	chemical spill in particular area
•	fire
•	pandemic
•	loss of power
•	damage to building
•	loss of power
•	damage from chemical spill
Example sources of emergency or disaster events are:
•	smoking in building
•	earthquake
•	disaster in neighboring company facility
•	storm
•	disgruntled employee
•	power generator failure
Emergency/Incident Reporting Procedure Steps
If you detect a potential emergency situation, take the following steps.  


First Response During an Emergency

Ensure that staff, visitors, contractors, and public 
are safe before conducting other steps.

If possible, take the following steps:
(If life threatening situation, evacuate premises)

1.	Briefly assess situation using Initial Incident Report. 

Note the following:
	Contact Information
	What is the Emergency?
	Type of incident
	Time of incident
	Location incident
	Who was notified
	What action has been taken

2.	Activate alarm, if necessary (e.g., in case of fire)

3.	Alert Floor/Area Warden, if required

4.	Alert Emergency Response Team Leader (ERTL) and/or:
	Alert the Emergency Response Team Deputy Manager (ERTDM).
	Alert the Facility Security Manager
	Alert a Senior Management Staff Member

5.	Alert Public Authorities (Police, Fire, and/or Ambulance service), if required
	Dial [911] and report your name, company, location, time, a brief description of incident

6.	Evacuate Area:
	For example, if fire, use General Emergency & Fire Evacuation Procedure
	For example, if bomb threat, use Bomb Threat Procedure

7.	If injuries:
	Ensure that you are safe and will not injure yourself
	Use Medical & First Aid Procedure

Procedures
Apart from the aid of public authorities, such as the police, fire, and ambulance services, and the direction of the Crisis Management Team (CMT), Foam Supplies, Inc.’s emergency response plan is the key internal emergency response in a crisis situation.  Since a quick response is necessary in a crisis situation, the teams responsible for the following procedures must react without delay and without waiting for instructions from the Crisis Management Team. 
The emergency response plan will ensure the following procedures are in place:
 ERP 1 – Emergency Incident Reporting Procedure
1.	ERP 2 – General/Fire Evacuation Procedure
2.	ERP 3 – Medical/First Aid Procedure
3.	ERP 4 – Bomb Threat Procedure

•	Makes recommendations based on information received from rescue operators and from health authorities
Rescue Staff

•	Work closely with fire and ambulance departments
•	Coordinate and liaison with external search and rescue

Incident Prevention Phase
In the event an emergency cannot be prevented from becoming a disaster, this phase attempts to prevent further damage by:
o	Administer first aid;
o	Move items to second floor;
o	Prevent water damage; and/or
o	Ensure evacuation.
Incident Monitoring Phase
This phase involves continuous monitoring of the incident to ensure that it does not progress.
Emergency Response Team Structure, Roles, and Responsibilities
An emergency response team is generally responsible for:
•	personnel evacuations,
•	internal rescue operations,
•	medical assistance, and
•	incident containment

EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAM STRUCTURE, ROLES, AND RESPONSIBILITIES

Emergency Response Team Leader (ERTL)
•	Primary director of emergency response team with overall responsibility for emergency response phase.
•	Coordinates emergency response activities together with ERTDM
•	Assesses situation and escalate emergency together with other Senior Management and ERT members
•	Mobilizes ERT
•	Primary responsible for formal plan activation, incident assessment, event logging, and notifications
•	Primary liaison with external authorities
•	Primary responsible for establishing Crisis Management Center

Emergency Response Team Deputy Manager (ERTDM)
•	Second in command director of emergency response phase and team.
•	Together with ERTL, coordinates emergency response activities
•	Together with ERTL, mobilizes ERT
•	Together with ERTL, responsible for plan activation, incident assessment, event logging, and notifications
•	Secondary liaison with external authorities
•	Secondary responsible for establishing Crisis Management Center

Facility Security Manager
•	Provide aid and support to ERT Leader during incidents on premises
•	Assists during evacuation
•	Controls access to facilities
•	Primary responsible for establishing Crisis Management Center

Security Guard
•	Provides support to ERT during incident
•	Assist during evacuation
•	Controls access to facilities

Evacuation Leaders (Floor Fire

nature of the incident and the industry that your company operates in, invocation of the plan may be from internal sources such as an employee who notices a problem, or from an external source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), National Guard, or American Red Cross.
There are numerous events that can trigger the activation of the emergency response plan. Some examples of these events are:
1.	a fire is detected;
2.	a gas leak is detected;
3.	a water leak occurs;
4.	a goods production machine is overheating; or
5.	a hostage situation is in progress.

The level of response will vary with each incident and there may be limited action, or a full response involving all team members and authorities.
The emergency response plan is designed to be executed prior to the execution of other business continuity plan documents; however, other plans such as the site management plan may be executed in parallel.
Incident Logging & Reporting Phase
When possible, the Emergency Incident Reporting Procedure shall be used to log an emergency incident.  The Initial Incident Report shall be completed with the following information:
•	Contact information – name, phone, date, and time;
•	Description of emergency – problem description, injuries, property damage;
•	Time of emergency event;
•	Location of emergency;
•	Who was notified; and 
•	What actions have been taken
This form shall be delivered to the ERT Leader, Senior Management member, or other ERT Member.

Incident Evacuation Phase
If the emergency situation is life threatening, evacuate premises immediately by following procedures for:
•	Fire Evacuation
•	Bomb Threat
•	Chemical Spill
The ERT Leader shall ensure safety of personnel by ensuring appropriate evacuation procedure is followed.
Incident Assessment and Escalation Phase
The ERT Leader or other senior Management members are responsible for assessing the incident. 
The purpose of this assessment is to:
•	Determine the urgency of the current emergency situation;
•	Determi

cy response plan is to protect life by:
1.	preventing injury;
2.	providing shelter; and
3.	evacuating the premises.
Additional objectives are to:
1.	mitigate the threat of an emergency or disaster situation;
2.	control and terminate the emergency or incident  as quickly as possible;
3.	prevent a minor incident from becoming a major disaster;
4.	familiarize all members and staff with procedures;
5.	protect environment;
6.	protect company assets;
7.	determine unsafe hazardous conditions and contaminations; and
8.	minimize impact to business.
Assumptions
This plan has been developed with the following assumptions:
•	All threats will be treated as genuine, until the incident investigation and assessment proves otherwise;
•	The Emergency Response Team will be comprised of sufficient number of staff to ensure a satisfactory turnout in the event of an emergency.

Emergency Response Plan High-level Process Flow
During the emergency response phase and site crisis management phase, the Crisis Management Center will be opened and CMT team members will gather to determine if a disaster is to be declared.  The following diagram illustrates the relationship between the ERP, SCMP, and the Business Area Recovery Plans:

The following process flow describes example high-level steps and actions conducted during the ERP phase.  Activities in the plan start whenever there is a threat of disaster or an actual emergency situation. 

ERP Sub-phases
The ERP phase is divided into the following sub-phases:
1.	Plan Activation Phase
2.	Incident Logging & Reporting Phase
3.	Incident Evacuation Phase
4.	Incident Assessment and Escalation Phase
5.	Incident Mitigation and Prevention
6.	Incident Monitoring Phase

Plan Activation Phase
The emergency response plan may be activated as a response to any event that threatens the safety of employees, corporate assets, or environment.  Activation of the emergency response plan occurs as a result of receiving notification of an emergency. Depending on the

pplies to all Foam Supplies, Inc. business facilities and locations.  Each site shall define, approve, and implement an emergency response plan which includes essential activities, procedures, and tasks necessary to ensure an effective response.
Executive Sponsor
Foam Supplies, Inc. assigns a senior management member to be the “Executive Sponsor” who approves, sponsors, and provides full support the development and implementation of the organization-wide business continuity program and its constituent parts including this policy, emergency response plan, and other associated business continuity plan documents.  The executive sponsor approves the budget and resources required, and delegates authority to the emergency response team and team leader to manage, coordinate, and oversee the emergency response plan design, development, implementation, maintenance, and assessment.
Review and Compliance
Foam Supplies, Inc. has established an annual review and assessment for this policy.  
Staff responsible
Foam Supplies, Inc. business continuity and recovery teams have the responsibility to know this policy and understand and adhere to the standards and procedures established in this policy. It is the responsibility of all staff to be aware of their departments and/or business unit’s business continuity plan and its associated documents.
Violations
Any employee and/or contractor or service provider found to have violated this policy may be subject to legal actions such as termination.  
Emergency Response Plan 
Purpose
The purpose of the emergency response plan is to:

1.	Provide a managed, coordinated, and effective response to the immediate physical effects of an emergency or crisis situation.  

2.	To ensure where an emergency situation is identified the potential for an emergency is minimized as low as reasonably practicable and there are practicable contingency plans in place in the vent of the emergency actually occurring.

formate in the past five years. 

The emergency response program
Introduction
This Emergency Response Plan contains predetermined guidelines and procedures to ensure the safety, health, and welfare of staff, and an immediate response to an emergency or disaster situation.  An emergency is any disruptive or harmful event that endangers people, environment, or an organization’s property and assets. Emergencies can be small, as in a fire contained by employees using firefighting equipment, or large, as in a disaster resulting from an earthquake or a tornado.  Example emergency events are:
•	explosion
•	overheated equipment
•	airplane crash
•	chemical spill in particular area
•	fire
•	pandemic
•	loss of power
•	damage to building
•	loss of power
•	damage from chemical spill
Example sources of emergency or disaster events are:
•	smoking in building
•	earthquake
•	disaster in neighboring company facility
•	storm
•	disgruntled employee
•	power generator failure

An emergency response plan deals with the immediate physical effects of a disaster and is used as an initial response.  The emergency response plan is closely associated with the business continuity plan.  The purpose of the business continuity plan is to ensure a prompt and efficient recovery of essential business operations.
Emergency Response Policy
Purpose
Foam Supplies, Inc. is committed to safeguarding the interests of clients, customers, and vendors in the event of an emergency or business disruption.  Foam Supplies, Inc. has therefore established a comprehensive organization-wide business continuity program to protect staff, safeguard corporate assets and environment, and to ensure continuous availability of its products and services.  To support the business continuity program, Foam Supplies, Inc. recognizes the need for an emergency response capability and provides this emergency response policy as part of the overall organization business continuity program policy.

A. Turn off pump
B. Turn off B-side chemical ball valves nearest the filter 
C. Let the tanker sit for approximately three minutes, then open the ball valve (for B-side only) to drain lines into tanks
D. This step should be done twice.

Once the pressure is relieved, disconnect the hoses and drain transfer hoses into a bucket.  Clean the fitting and spills.  Close all ball valves and have a second person verify and check off on the unloading check sheet.
B. Turn off the blow-down on the tank and then reconnect the nitrogen.
6. Review the Driver’s Final Papers
A. Review the driver’s unload arrival and departure times.
B. If there was a problem or something you did not agree on, document them and have them approved by Lonnie, Jim B, Mac, Karen or David. The time allowed for unloading is two hours.  This time should begin from the time the truck was scheduled to arrive.
C. If you agree with the papers, sign and note the finish time in the FSI “B-side and Polyol Log.”

The five-year accident history
Foam Supplies Inc. has not had any accidental releases of Methyl

es or other appropriate devices.
B. Check the pressure of the head space on the tank truck.  It must be 13psi or less.  If it is higher it must be blown down according to the “Tank truck pressure blow down procedure”.
C. Once the head space pressure is below 13psi the designated FSI employee will connect the vent lines from the storage tank to the tank truck and open the vent valves. They will then open the safety valves to each storage tank. (If they do not open check all emergency shut offs.)
D. Open both tank valves and the offload fitting valve.
E. Have the driver open the internal truck valve 
F. Confirm all valve positions and hose connections.
G. Open the external truck valve to begin chemical flow to the FSI offloading pump.  The FSI employee must remain throughout the entire offload continuously monitoring for any overfill or leakage.  In case of either occurring, the employee will activate the shut off to the safety valve, shut off the pump and close the internal valve of the tank truck.
H. When the truck is empty, shut the safety valves to the storage tanks, close the 2 tank valves, the off-load fitting valve and shut off the pump. Have the driver close the external truck valve then the internal truck valve.
I. The FSI employee will close the storage tank vent and disconnect the vent from the tank truck.  
J. The FSI employee will open the nitrogen valve to pressurize the storage tanks.
K. The truck driver will open the hose vent and drain into a metal bucket.  Be sure to use grounding clamp between the tank truck and the bucket.
L. The FSI employee will open the off-load fitting drain valve and drain into the same metal bucket.  Be sure to use grounding clamp between the storage tank piping and the bucket.
M. The FSI employee will transfer the MF from the bucket to a metal drum situated for this purpose. Use a grounding clamp between the bucket and the drum.
N. The FSI employee will disconnect the hose from the tank truck and cap it with the camlock cap

METHYL FORMATE (ECOMATE) TANK TRUCK UNLOADING PROCEDURE
1. Bulk Truck Arrival
A. After having gone through the proper procedure for receiving tank trucks, have the truck back into the loading spot. (See Proposed procedure for receiving tank trucks of material at FSI ST. Louis) Chock both sides of the wheels on the back of the trailer.  Be sure the chocks are placed flush against the tire.  Have the driver shut off the motor and the electric to the tank truck.
B. Obtain shipping papers from driver and document the following in the FSI “Delivery Log” (located on the shipping and receiving desk.)                                                                                
a. Arrival Time:
b. Lot Number
c. Compare Bill of Lading with FSI Purchase Order to assure proper goods are delivered.
d. Designated FSI employee will open sight gauges and confirm we have enough room to off load the amount on the truck.
C. Connect the grounding cable from the storage tank to the tank truck ground post.
D.  Have the driver provide a 1 Gallon Retain Sample- The can should be labeled with a type of material, manufacturer, lot number, date of arrival.   
2. Q.C. Test of Material Received
A. With the sample received in the Step #2 above, follow the Q.C. procedures as outlined in the Product Specifications binder.
B. The Q.C. tests are designed to determine that the material received will react within the specific ranges set by FSI.
Once the tests are completed, have QC/QA manager approve the material for unloading.  If the material does not pass, consult the QC/QA manager for Return Authorization.
3. Unloading - After the material has been approved by the QC/QA Department.
A. Have the truck driver connect the transfer hose to the offload fittings.  The fittings must be locked with plastic ti

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
A Process Safety Management (PSM) review was completed in May 2020 by FSI for methyl formate. Initial training on the PSM for methyl formate shall be provided to each employee presently involved in operating a process. Each employee shall be trained in an overview of the process before being involved in operating the process.  Refresher training shall be provided at least every three years, more often if necessary, to each employee involved in operating a process. This training will be documented with a record that contains the identity of the trained employee, the date of the training, and the means used to verify the training. The complete PSM is available upon request. 

PROCEDURE FOR FILLING THE METHYL FORMATE DAY TANK
1.	Decide which storage tank to pull chemical out of.
2.	Confirm the storage tank pressure is at 15 psi
3.	Confirm there is enough chemical in the tank to fill the day tank by opening sight gauges.
4.	Open the safety valve to the selected storage tank.
5.	Open the bottom tank valve.
6.	Open the valve going from the storage tank to the day tank.
7.	Confirm the net weight of the day tank.
8.	Blow down the day tank pressure
9.	Open the day tank inlet valves.
10.	Fill the day tank to 2,500 lbs. net weight.
11.	Close the inlet valves to the day tank.
12.	Close the blow down valve to the day tank.
13.	Pressurize the day tank to 25 psi gauge.
14.	Record the net weight of the day tank.
15.	Close the valve from the storage tank to the day tank.
16.	Close the bottom tank valve.
17.	Close the safety valve to the storage t

past five years. 

Foam Supplies, Inc. has concluded that the use of Ecomate TM (methyl formate) has been shown to be Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) for the intended use on the basis of scientific procedures, in accordance with 21 C.F.R. 170.3. This conclusion is supported by the determination of an independent panel of qualified experts, which evaluated the safety of Ecomate TM methyl formate and determined the general recognition of safety of the substance under its intended condition of use. The complete GRAS report is available upon request. 
 
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed in May 2005 by RRS Engineering, LLC. with a review team of personnel from Foam Supplies Inc. The report was prepared by RRS Engineering, LLC. and summarizes the findings and recommendations that were developed during the PHA. The PHA included What-IF studies covering multiple scenarios, the potential consequences of those scenarios, existing systems / safeguards already in place, and recommended actions to take. The complete PHA is available upon request.
 
Operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who operate or maintain the system. The following procedures have been developed:
•	Operating Procedure - Methyl formate System;
•	Off-loading (Hazardous Chemical Delivery) Procedure;
•	Emergency Response Procedure; and
•	Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) Procedures.

The operating procedures will be reviewed by Foam Supplies Inc. as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, and equipment, and changes to stationary sources. Foam Supplies Inc. will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate.
Foam Supplies Inc. has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space

Foam Supplies Inc. operates the Earth City Power Facility on an industrially zoned parcel in Earth City, Missouri. The site is situated approximately 5-miles southeast of St. Charles, MO, approximately 20-miles northwest of St. Louis and is along the Missouri River. Methyl formate (Ecomate) is unloaded from a tanker truck into storage tanks that are pressurized with nitrogen. The Methyl formate is fed to a day tank on a batch basis. It is then pumped to an in-line blender where it is blended with polyols and/or isocyanates. The solution is then charged to portable tanks for shipment to customers.

Methyl formate will be stored as a pressurized liquid in two adjacent 4,000-gallon tanks on the back side of the main building. The presence of approximately 230,000 pounds (i.e., greater than 10,000 pounds) of Methyl formate requires compliance with EPA’s RMP rules (Risk Management Program, 40 CFR 68). The pressure in the storage tanks is maintained by pressurized nitrogen. The feed flows from each tank separately to be pumped to an in-line blender where it is blended with polyols and/or isocyanates. This solution is then charged to portable tanks for shipment to customers. Mix tanks are also provided for mixing large batches of a blend at one time for shipment to customers. These are charged from the storage tanks. The blended solutions are used by customers to produce various foam products. A drumming area also provides capability to drum pure Methyl formate for shipment to customers.

The facility is subject to Program 1 requirements as specified in 40 CFR 68 based on the WCS run on June 10, 2021. Foam Supplies, Inc. has passive mitigation around the methyl formate bulk tanks, the WCS run including the passive mitigation resulted in a distance to end point of 0.05 miles. This WCS run did not show residential population receptors or non-residential receptors within the radius.
